Award.AwardTitle: Neural mechanisms of age-related changes in perceptual and memory decisions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Decision-making abilities change as we age. While some changes are beneficial, such as improvements arising from accumulated experience, others are not. For example, older people are typically more cautious than is optimal in their decision-making, and are less apt to altar their decision strategies even when it would be advantageous. These changes can affect our health and quality of life. Despite the importance of decision making to healthy living, the neural mechanisms of the decision-making process, from perception to action, and how those mechanisms change in aging, are poorly understood. With the support of the National Science Foundation, Dr. Mark Wheeler and his research team at the Georgia Institute of Technology will use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to identify how age-related differences in decisions about what we perceive and remember correspond with changes in brain function. Dr. Wheeler's research strategy is to investigate decision making as a multi-stage process in which incoming information is analyzed, evidence relevant to choices are extracted from that information and accumulated over time, and a decision is reached when there is enough evidence. Different stages of the decision process have been found to have different fMRI activation profiles, making it possible to identify whether specific stages change in healthy aging. It is predicted that, as we age, certain aspects of this multi-stage process change while others do not, and that these changes will be related to functional changes in the brain. For example, the increased caution found in many older individuals should be associated with a greater accumulation of fMRI activation prior to a decision, while a decrease in the fidelity of information processing in memory and perception should be associated with slower rates of accumulating fMRI activation. The research will also use machine learning approaches to test the degree to which the timing and amount of fMRI activity predict decision outcome. By investigating changes in neural activity as decisions develop in time, this project will identify which neural processes are most important in reaching a decision, and which change the most as we age. Such knowledge will be useful in the development of strategies or methods to improve decision-making abilities in later years.

This project will have broader impacts on health, science training, and outreach. The research will address issues related to human health and well-being, such as how decision-making abilities in people who are in good health differ from people with Alzheimer's disease. The research program emphasizes mentoring of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in learning the scientific process, including hands-on training in hypothesis generation, experimental design, data collection, processing, analysis, and interpretation, and public speaking/presentation. Undergraduate researchers with advanced projects are encouraged to present their findings at local and international conferences. Research findings are presented in scientific and public formats, including scientific meetings and publications, web sites, classes, and community seminars and forums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this research proposal was to investigate age-related differences in cognitive and neural measures of decision making about perceptions and memories. As we age, we tend to be more susceptible to sensory noise, to be more conservative in our decision-making, and to disregard informative cues that are likely to help us make good choices. We have very little understanding about how changes in the nervous system from young to older adulthood may mediate changes in behavior. We have conducted a series of perceptual and memory choice experiments in groups of younger and older adults in order to investigate these issues. In one formative study of perceptual choice in younger adults (Dunovan and Wheeler, 2018), we found that informative cues about an impending categorical choice modulated brain activity prior to and during choice behavior, that is consistent with "accumulation to boundary" models of information processing. A second study that included older and younger adults found that, despite predictions based on the literature, older adult behavior was influenced by informative cues (Walker and Wheeler, in prep). In this study, and a third study (Wheeler, Carlson, and Braunlich, in prep), we found that older adults were more sensitive than younger adults to sensory noise, but that brain activity did not change obviously as a function of age when perceptual decisions were accurate. A fourth study tested the degree to which dynamically changing cue probabilities modulate neural activity in younger adults (Braunlich, Carlson, and Wheeler, in prep) and found that sensory and motor brain regions tracked the change in probability over time. Data from a fifth study investigating age-related effects in associative memory are currently being analyzed and a report is in prep (Carlson and Wheeler, in prep). Overall we have found that older adults are more sensitive to perceptual noise, but when their decisions are accurate, there are few notable differences with younger adults.
